processingItems.note: Checks exit reason.
User said things like "I'm done thanks" or "Thank you, goodbye" at the NLU.
User needs to be transferred to a customer service representative. This may happen due to maxnomatch or maxnoinput error, general application error, representative request, for example.

Checks which FAQ message needs to be played.
Since this sample design only contains the one FAQ entry for lost luggage, that’s what we'll play.
Plays FAQ message.

payload.displayText: Oh no! We can help. Just let us know within 4 hours of arriving at your destination and we'll  take care of the rest.  You can report lost luggage at the ticket counter, baggage claim, or by calling us at 800-333-5830.
payload.ttsText: Oh no! We can help. Just let us know within 4 hours of arriving at your destination and we'll  take care of the rest.  You can report lost luggage at the ticket counter, baggage claim, or by calling us at 800-333-5830.

processingItems.note:
Plays flight status information.
Since this sample design doesn't have a data access node for checking the actual flight status, the bot will play a placeholder message.

payload.displayText: Your flight to Chicago is leaving on time from Boston at 3pm today. You're scheduled to arrive at 5pm local time.
payload.ttsText: Your flight to Chicago is leaving on time from Boston at 3pm today. You're scheduled to arrive at 5pm local time.

dataaccessNode.name: bf1055_SubmitFlight_DA
dataaccessNode.description:
This data access node is called when the user has confirmed they would like to book the proposed itinerary. An outside endpoint is called using the flight information, and a Boolean response is returned.
In the Integration section, "Enable client-side fetching" is selected. This means that it is assumed that the client that will run this bot knows what to do with, and how to respond to this data access request.
Note: When you try this app with the Mix demo client, it already knows to map the name of this data access node to this backend function path:
demo.mix.nuance.com/api/book-flight-quickstart

outputVariables.name: isFlightConfirmed
outputVariables.description: True if the flight was successfully booked.

processingItems.note: Plays a confirmation message to make sure that all the collected flight details are correct.

payload.displayText: Here's what I got: a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] leaving on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb].
payload.ttsText: Here's what I got: a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] leaving on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb].

processingItems.note:
To book a flight, we need to collect the departure city, arrival city and departure date. In this node, we check if the user already provided any of this information.
• If the user didn't (that is, the entities are still all null in the NLU recognition results), we prompt the user for more details about the flight they are looking for (go to bf1015_AskFlightDetails_QA).
• If the user did provide any of the required slots (for example, "I need to book a flight to Atlanta"), we only ask for the pieces of information that we still need, like departure city and date.

lhsVariable.name: askGeneralBookFlight
lhsVariable.description: True if caller didn't mention departure city, arrival city and departure date in their intent.

processingItems.note:
If the caller didn't give any information about their flight, we ask them to provide more details. The goal is to collect multiple entities at once, instead of collecting them from answers to separate questions.
This node is set up to collect eBookFlight, which is a dummy entity (with no specific values). What the user says will be used to populate other entities with the required information.
We've also included an option for the user to get the list of cities they can choose from (that is, by saying "List the cities"). We handle this option as a command override ("cities" is a value of eGlobalCommands, the global command entity for this project). Under User Input, check out the optional Command Overrides section.

processingItems.note:
The next step is to collect the user's intent. This question and answer node works with a companion intent mapper node, which routes the intent to the corresponding destination.  Because this is a demo app, we've included an option for the user to get a list of things they can do in the system (that is, "What are my options?").
We handle this option as a command override ("options" is a value of eGlobalCommands, the global command entity for this project). Check out the optional Command Overrides section, under User Input.

Additionally, notice that some messages are intentionally blank for the Digital VA text channel, since, in this case, the VA goes straight to question and answer node ma1013_MenuOptions_QA to explicitly list out all available options on the first step. Messages that only have TTS but no rich text version are only used in the Voice VA version of the bot (IVR channel), and not in the Digital VA text version.

processingItems.note:
This node illustrates how we can support both directed dialog and open dialog.
We give the user a set of menu options (directed dialog), while also collecting the NLU intent (open dialog) so the user isn't limited to just these options—they can tell us any intent within the NLU grammar.
We handle the menu options as command overrides ("book flight", "flight status", and "lost luggage" are values of eGlobalCommands, the global command entity for this project). Under User Input, check out the Collect section, and the optional DTMF and Command Overrides sections.
We set this up for all channels but, in real life, this would normally apply to IVR integrations only.

processingItems.note: We greet the user.  The messaging is customized per channel/modality as needed.  You'll see throughout, we use a node naming convention with an node ID (ma1005), short description, and the node type (MS).  This helps us keep the nodes in rough sequence order, and be able to identify nodes easily.

payload.displayText: Windborne Airlines. Thanks for flying with us!
payload.ttsText: Windborne Airlines. Thanks for flying with us!

payload.displayText: Hi I'm Windborne Airlines' virtual assistant.
Where are you going and when?
payload.ttsText: Where are you going and when?  You can also say "List the cities."

payload.displayText: When would you like to go?
payload.ttsText: When would you like to go?

payload.displayText: And where are you leaving from?
payload.ttsText: And where are you leaving from? Or say "List the cities."

payload.displayText: Here's what I got: a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] leaving on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb].
payload.ttsText: Here's what I got: a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] leaving on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb].

payload.displayText: I can help with lots of things, like your Flight Status, Booking a Flight or Looking for Lost Luggage. What would you like to do?
payload.ttsText: I can help with lots of things, like your Flight Status, Booking a Flight or Looking for Lost Luggage. What would you like to do?

payload.displayText: I found a flight leaving on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb] at 11am, arriving at 2pm, local time for $320.  Would you like to book it?
payload.ttsText: I found a flight leaving on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb] at 11am, arriving at 2pm, local time for $320.  Would you like to book it?

payload.displayText: Oh no! We can help. Just let us know within 4 hours of arriving at your destination and we'll  take care of the rest.  You can report lost luggage at the ticket counter, baggage claim, or by calling us at 800-333-5830.
payload.ttsText: Oh no! We can help. Just let us know within 4 hours of arriving at your destination and we'll  take care of the rest.  You can report lost luggage at the ticket counter, baggage claim, or by calling us at 800-333-5830.

payload.displayText: Just a minute while I connect you with someone to help.
Please wait a moment while I connect you to an agent.

payload.displayText: Sure I can help you with that.
payload.ttsText: Sure I can help you with that.

Your flight to Chicago is leaving on time from Boston at 3pm today. You're scheduled to arrive at 5pm local time.

payload.ttsText: Where are you travelling from? Our departure cities are Atlanta, Cleveland, New York City, Phoenix, and San Francisco.

payload.displayText: Sorry, just tell me where do you want to leave from.
payload.ttsText: If you'd like to leave from Atlanta, press 1. From Cleveland, press 2. New York City, press 3. Phoenix, press 4. Or, San Francisco, press 5.

payload.displayText: Please choose one of these destinations.
payload.ttsText: Where would you like to go? Our destinations are Atlanta, Cleveland, New York City, Phoenix, and San Francisco.

payload.displayText: Sorry, just tell me where you're travelling.
payload.ttsText: If you'd like to go to Atlanta, press 1. Cleveland, press 2. New York City, press 3. Phoenix, press 4. Or, San Francisco, press 5.

payload.displayText: Sorry, do you want me to continue?
payload.ttsText: There is a flight on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb] at 11am, arriving at 2pm, local time for $320. To book this flight, press 1. Othwerwise, press 2.

payload.displayText: I need more information. Would you repeat your question in a different way?
payload.ttsText: Tell me again. How can I help you today? Or say "what are my options?"

payload.displayText: Sorry, I'm still learning. Please rephrase your question differently.
payload.ttsText: In a few words, please tell me what you're calling about. For example, you could say "I'd like to book a flight" or "hear my flight status". Or, you can also say "what are my options"? So, what can I help you with?

payload.displayText: I can help you with things like your Flight Status, Booking a Flight or Looking for Lost Luggage. So, what do you need help with?
payload.ttsText: I can help you with things like your Flight Status, Booking a Flight or Looking for Lost Luggage. So, what do you need help with?

payload.displayText: If you need to change anything, just let me know. Otherwise, do you want me to continue?
payload.ttsText: You're looking for a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb]. If you need to change anything, just let me know. For example, you can say "Actually, I'm leaving on December 1st". Otherwise, should I go ahead and lookup some flights for you?

payload.displayText: All set! I used your Visa on file to book your flight and you're all ready to travel to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb]. I've sent a copy of your itinerary to your gmail address on file.
payload.ttsText: All set! I used your Visa on file to book your flight and you're all ready to travel to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] on [eDepartureDate|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb]. I've sent a copy of your itinerary to your gmail address on file.

payload.displayText: Also, next time, try typing it like this: Book a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] on [June 23rd|20eda184-3749-4218-a49d-ac7fc700d9bb].
payload.ttsText: Also, next time, try saying it like this: Book a flight from [eDepartureCity|c1367222-01a9-47e4-a093-f7c234d08619] to [eArrivalCity|38f0085d-43d4-4ea2-806f-5e6671cf5881] on June 23rd.

payload.displayText: I can help you with things like your Flight Status, Booking a Flight or Looking for Lost Luggage. So, what do you need help with?
payload.ttsText: To check to the status of your flight, press 1. To book a flight, press 2. Or, if you need help with lost luggage, press 3.

payload.displayText: You can leave from Atlanta, Cleveland, New York City, Phoenix or San Francisco.
